sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion
bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand crowns,
and, as thou sayest, charged my brother, on his
blessing, to breed me well: and there begins my
sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school,
and report speaks goldenly of his profit: for my
part, he keeps me rustically at home, or, to
speak more properly, stays me here at home unkept;
for call you that keeping for a gentleman of my
birth, that differs not from the stalling of an
ox? His horses are bred better; for, besides that
they are fair with their feeding, they are taught
their manage, and to that end riders dearly hired:
but I, his brother, gain nothing under him but
growth; for the which his animals on his dunghills
are as much bound to him as I. Besides this
nothing that he so plentifully gives me, the
something that nature gave me his countenance
seems to take from me: he lets me feed with his
hinds, bars me the place of a brother, and, as
much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my
education. This is it, Adam, that grieves me;
and the spirit of my father, which I think is
within me, begins to mutiny against this servitude:
I will no longer endure it, though yet I know no wise
remedy how to avoid it.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.ab: Yonder comes my master, your brother.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will shake
me up.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Now, sir! what make you here?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Nothing: I am not taught to make any thing.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: What mar you then, sir?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that which
God made, a poor unworthy brother of yours, with
idleness.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?
What prodigal portion have I spent, that I should come
to such penury?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Know you where you are, sir?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: O, sir, very well; here in your orchard.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Know you before whom, sir?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I know
you are my eldest brother; and, in the gentle
condition of blood, you should so know me. The
courtesy of nations allows you my better, in that
you are the first born; but the same tradition
takes not away my blood, were there twenty brothers
betwixt us: I have as much of my father in me as
you; albeit, I confess, your coming before me is
nearer to his reverence.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: What, boy!

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Come, come, elder brother, you are too young in this.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I am no villain; I am the youngest son of Sir
Rowland de Boys; he was my father, and he is
thrice a villain that says such a father begot
villains. Wert thou not my brother, I would not
take this hand from thy throat till this other
had pulled out thy tongue for saying so: thou hast
railed on thyself.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.ab: Sweet masters, be patient: for your father's
remembrance, be at accord.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Let me go, I say.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I will not, till I please: you shall hear me. My
father charged you in his will to give me good
education: you have trained me like a peasant,
obscuring and hiding from me all gentleman-like
qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong
in me, and I will no longer endure it: therefore
allow me such exercises as may become a gentleman,
or give me the poor allottery my father left me by
testament; with that I will go buy my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: And what wilt thou do? beg, when that is spent?
Well, sir, get you in: I will not long be troubled
with you; you shall have some part of your will: I
pray you, leave me.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I will no further offend you than becomes me for my
good.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Get you with him, you old dog.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.ab: Is âold dogâ my reward? Most true, I have lost
my teeth in your service. God be with my old master!
he would not have spoke such a word.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Is it even so? begin you to grow upon me? I will
physic your rankness, and yet give no thousand crowns
neither. Holla, Dennis!

sp.speaker: Dennis
sp.ab: Calls your worship?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Was not Charles, the duke's wrestler, here to speak
with me?

sp.speaker: Dennis
sp.ab: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes
access to you.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Call him in.
'Twill be a good way; and to-morrow the wrestling is.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: Good morrow to your worship.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Good Monsieur Charles, what's the new news at the new
court?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: There's no news at the court, sir, but the old
news: that is, the old duke is banished by his
younger brother the new duke; and three or four
loving lords have put themselves into voluntary
exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich
the new duke; therefore he gives them good leave to
wander.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke's daughter, be
banished with her father?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: O, no; for the duke's daughter, her cousin, so
loves her, being ever from their cradles bred
together, that she would have followed her exile,
or have died to stay behind her. She is at the
court, and no less beloved of her uncle than his own
daughter; and never two ladies loved as they do.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Where will the old duke live?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: They say he is already in the forest of Arden,
and a many merry men with him; and there they
live like the old Robin Hood of England: they
say many young gentlemen flock to him every day,
and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the
golden world.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: What, you wrestle to-morrow before the new duke?

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with
a matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand
that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition
to come in disguised against me to try a fall.
To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he
that escapes me without some broken limb shall
acquit him well. Your brother is but young and
tender; and, for your love, I would be loath to
foil him, as I must, for my own honour, if he
come in: therefore, out of my love to you, I came
hither to acquaint you withal, that either you
might stay him from his intendment or brook such
disgrace well as he shall run into, in that it
is a thing of his own search and altogether against my
will.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which
thou shalt find I will most kindly requite. I
had myself notice of my brother's purpose herein
and have by underhand means laboured to dissuade
him from it, but he is resolute. I'll tell thee,
Charles: it is the stubbornest young fellow of
France, full of ambition, an envious emulator of
every man's good parts, a secret and villainous
contriver against me his natural brother: therefore
use thy discretion; I had as lief thou didst
break his neck as his finger. And thou wert best
look to't; for if thou dost him any slight disgrace
or if he do not mightily grace himself on thee,
he will practise against thee by poison, entrap
thee by some treacherous device and never leave
thee till he hath ta'en thy life by some indirect
means or other; for, I assure thee, and almost
with tears I speak it, there is not one so young
and so villainous this day living. I speak but
brotherly of him; but should I anatomize him to
thee as he is, I must blush and weep and thou must
look pale and wonder.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he
come to-morrow, I'll give him his payment: if
ever he go alone again, I'll never wrestle for prize
more: and so God keep your worship!

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Farewell, good Charles.
Now will I stir this gamester: I hope I shall
see an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not
why, hates nothing more than he. Yet he's gentle,
never schooled and yet learned, full of noble
device, of all sorts enchantingly beloved, and
indeed so much in the heart of the world, and
especially of my own people, who best know him,
that I am altogether misprised: but it shall not
be so long; this wrestler shall clear all: nothing
remains but that I kindle the boy thither; which now
I'll go about.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress
of; and would you yet I were merrier? Unless you
could teach me to forget a banished father, you
must not learn me how to remember any extraordinary
pleasure.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Herein I see thou lovest me not with the full
weight that I love thee. If my uncle, thy banished
father, had banished thy uncle, the duke my
father, so thou hadst been still with me, I could
have taught my love to take thy father for mine:
so wouldst thou, if the truth of thy love to me were
so righteously tempered as mine is to thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to
rejoice in yours.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: You know my father hath no child but I, nor none
is like to have: and, truly, when he dies, thou
shalt be his heir, for what he hath taken away
from thy father perforce, I will render thee
again in affection; by mine honour, I will; and
when I break that oath, let me turn monster:
therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports. Let me
see; what think you of falling in love?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal: but
love no man in good earnest; nor no further in
sport neither than with safety of a pure blush thou
mayst in honour come off again.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: What shall be our sport, then?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Let us sit and mock the good huswife Fortune from
her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed
equally.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I would we could do so, for her benefits are
mightily misplaced, and the bountiful blind woman doth
most mistake in her gifts to women.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: 'Tis true; for those that she makes fair she
scarce makes honest, and those that she makes honest
she makes very ill-favouredly.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, now thou goest from Fortune's office to
Nature's: Fortune reigns in gifts of the world, not in
the lineaments of Nature.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: No? when Nature hath made a fair creature, may
she not by Fortune fall into the fire? Though
Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune,
hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the
argument?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature,
when Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutter-off of
Nature's wit.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither,
but Nature's; who perceiveth our natural wits
too dull to reason of such goddesses and hath
sent this natural for our whetstone; for always
the dullness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits.
How now, wit! whither wander you?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Mistress, you must come away to your father.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Were you made the messenger?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: No, by mine honour, but I was bid to come for you.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Where learned you that oath, fool?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they
were good pancakes and swore by his honour the
mustard was naught: now I'll stand to it, the
pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet
was not the knight forsworn.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: How prove you that, in the great heap of your
knowledge?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and swear
by your beards that I am a knave.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: By our beards, if we had them, thou art.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: By my knavery, if I had it, then I were; but if
you swear by that that is not, you are not
forsworn: no more was this knight, swearing by
his honour, for he never had any; or if he had,
he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancakes
or that mustard.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Prithee, who is't that thou meanest?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: My father's love is enough to honour him: enough!
speak no more of him; you'll be whipped for taxation
one of these days.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: The more pity, that fools may not speak wisely what
wise men do foolishly.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: By my troth, thou sayest true; for since the
little wit that fools have was silenced, the
little foolery that wise men have makes a great show.
Here comes Monsieur Le Beau.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With his mouth full of news.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Which he will put on us, as pigeons feed their young.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Then shall we be news-crammed.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: All the better; we shall be the more marketable.
Bon jour, Monsieur Le Beau: what's the news?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Sport! of what colour?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: What colour, madam! how shall I answer you?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: As wit and fortune will.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Or as the Destinies decrees.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Well said: that was laid on with a trowel.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Nay, if I keep not my rank, â

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Thou losest thy old smell.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: You amaze me, ladies: I would have told you of good
wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Yet tell us the manner of the wrestling.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: I will tell you the beginning; and, if it please
your ladyships, you may see the end; for the best
is yet to do; and here, where you are, they are coming
to perform it.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Well, the beginning, that is dead and buried.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: There comes an old man and his three sons, â

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I could match this beginning with an old tale.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: Three proper young men, of excellent growth and
presence.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With bills on their necks, âBe it known unto all men
by these presents.â

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles,
the duke's wrestler; which Charles in a moment
threw him and broke three of his ribs, that there
is little hope of life in him: so he served the
second, and so the third. Yonder they lie; the
poor old man, their father, making such pitiful
dole over them that all the beholders take his part
with weeping.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Alas!

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have
lost?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: Why, this that I speak of.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Thus men may grow wiser every day: it is the
first time that ever I heard breaking of ribs was
sport for ladies.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Or I, I promise thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: But is there any else longs to see this broken
music in his sides? is there yet another dotes
upon rib-breaking? Shall we see this wrestling,
cousin?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: You must, if you stay here; for here is the place
appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to
perform it.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Yonder, sure, they are coming: let us now stay and see
it.
sp.stage: Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: Come on: since the youth will not be entreated, his
own peril on his forwardness.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Is yonder the man?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: Even he, madam.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Alas, he is too young! yet he looks successfully.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: How now, daughter and cousin! are you crept hither to
see the wrestling?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: You will take little delight in it, I can tell
you; there is such odds in the man. In pity of
the challenger's youth I would fain dissuade him,
but he will not be entreated. Speak to him, ladies;
see if you can move him.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: Do so: I'll not be by.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: Monsieur the challenger, the princess calls for you.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I attend them with all respect and duty.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: No, fair princess; he is the general challenger:
I come but in, as others do, to try with him the
strength of my youth.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for
your years. You have seen cruel proof of this
man's strength: if you saw yourself with your
eyes or knew yourself with your judgement, the
fear of your adventure would counsel you to a
more equal enterprise. We pray you, for your own
sake, to embrace your own safety and give over this
attempt.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Do, young sir; your reputation shall not therefore
be misprised: we will make it our suit to the duke
that the wrestling might not go forward.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I beseech you, punish me not with your hard
thoughts; wherein I confess me much guilty, to
deny so fair and excellent ladies any thing. But
let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me
to my trial: wherein if I be foiled, there is
but one shamed that was never gracious; if killed,
but one dead that is willing to be so: I shall
do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament
me, the world no injury, for in it I have nothing;
only in the world I fill up a place, which may be
better supplied when I have made it empty.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: The little strength that I have, I would it were with
you.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: And mine, to eke out hers.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Fare you well: pray heaven I be deceived in you!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Your heart's desires be with you!

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: Come, where is this young gallant that is so desirous
to lie with his mother earth?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Ready, sir; but his will hath in it a more modest
working.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: You shall try but one fall.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.ab: No, I warrant your grace, you shall not entreat
him to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him
from a first.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: You mean to mock me after, you should not have mocked
me before: but come your ways.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Now Hercules be thy speed, young man!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow
by the leg.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O excellent young man!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who
should down.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: No more, no more.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Yes, I beseech your grace: I am not yet well breathed.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: How dost thou, Charles?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.ab: He cannot speak, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.ab: Bear him away. What is thy name, young man?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
Boys.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: I would thou hadst been son to some man else:
The world esteemed thy father honourable,
But I did find him still mine enemy:
Thou shouldst have better pleased me with this deed,
Hadst thou descended from another house.
But fare thee well; thou art a gallant youth:
I would thou hadst told me of another father. Exeunt Duke Fred., train, and Le Beau.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son,
His youngest son; and would not change that calling,
To be adopted heir to Frederick.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul,
And all the world was of my father's mind:
Had I before known this young man his son,
I should have given him tears unto entreaties,
Ere he should thus have ventured.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Gentle cousin,
Let us go thank him and encourage him:
My father's rough and envious disposition
Sticks me at heart. Sir, you have well deserved:
If you do keep your promises in love
But justly, as you have exceeded all promise,
Your mistress shall be happy.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Gentleman, Giving him a chain from her neck.
Wear this for me, one out of suits with fortune,
That could give more, but that her hand lacks means.
Shall we go, coz?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Ay. Fare you well, fair gentleman.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Can I not say, I thank you? My better parts
Are all thrown down, and that which here stands up
Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: He calls us back: my pride fell with my fortunes;
I'll ask him what he would. Did you call, sir?
Sir, you have wrestled well and overthrown
More than your enemies.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Will you go, coz?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Have with you. Fare you well. Exeunt Rosalind and Celia.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.
O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown!
Or Charles or something weaker masters thee. Re-enter LE BEAU.

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.l: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you
To leave this place. Albeit you have deserved
High commendation, true applause and love,
Yet such is now the duke's condition
That he misconstrues all that you have done.
The duke is humorous: what he is indeed,
More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I thank you, sir: and, pray you, tell me this;
Which of the two was daughter of the duke
That here was at the wrestling?

sp.speaker: Le Beau
sp.l: Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners;
But yet indeed the smaller is his daughter:
The other is daughter to the banished duke,
And here detained by her usurping uncle,
To keep his daughter company; whose loves
Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters.
But I can tell you that of late this duke
Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece,
Grounded upon no other argument
But that the people praise her for her virtues
And pity her for her good father's sake;
And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady
Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well:
Hereafter, in a better world than this,
I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I rest much bounden to you: fare you well. Exit Le Beau.
Thus must I from the smoke into the smother;
From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother:
But heavenly Rosalind! Exit.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy! not a
word?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Not one to throw at a dog.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away
upon curs; throw some of them at me; come, lame me
with reasons.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Then there were two cousins laid up; when the
one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad
without any.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: But is all this for your father?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: No, some of it is for my child's father. O, how full
of briers is this working-day world!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in
holiday foolery: if we walk not in the trodden paths,
our very petticoats will catch them.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my
heart.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Hem them away.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I would try, if I could cry âhemâ and have him.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O, they take the part of a better wrestler than
myself!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: O, a good wish upon you! you will try in time,
in despite of a fall. But, turning these jests
out of service, let us talk in good earnest: is
it possible, on such a sudden, you should fall
into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's
youngest son?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: The duke my father loved his father dearly.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his
son dearly? By this kind of chase, I should hate
him, for my father hated his father dearly; yet I hate
not Orlando.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Why should I not? doth he not deserve well?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Let me love him for that, and do you love him because
I do. Look, here comes the duke.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: With his eyes full of anger.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste
And get you from our court.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Me, uncle?

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: You, cousin:
Within these ten days if that thou be'st found
So near our public court as twenty miles,
Thou diest for it.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I do beseech your grace,
Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me:
If with myself I hold intelligence
Or have acquaintance with mine own desires,
If that I do not dream or be not frantic, â
As I do trust I am not â then, dear uncle,
Never so much as in a thought unborn
Did I offend your highness.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Thus do all traitors:
If their purgation did consist in words,
They are as innocent as grace itself:
Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor:
Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Thou art thy father's daughter; there's enough.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: So was I when your highness took his dukedom;
So was I when your highness banished him:
Treason is not inherited, my lord;
Or, if we did derive it from our friends,
What's that to me? my father was no traitor:
Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much
To think my poverty is treacherous.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Ay, Celia; we stayed her for your sake,
Else had she with her father ranged along.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: I did not then entreat to have her stay;
It was your pleasure and your own remorse:
I was too young that time to value her;
But now I know her: if she be a traitor,
Why so am I; we still have slept together,
Rose at an instant, learned, played, eat together,
And wheresoe'er we went, like Juno's swans,
Still we went coupled and inseparable.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: She is too subtle for thee; and her smoothness,
Her very silence and her patience
Speak to the people, and they pity her.
Thou art a fool: she robs thee of thy name;
And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
When she is gone. Then open not thy lips:
Firm and irrevocable is my doom
Which I have passed upon her; she is banished.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege:
I cannot live out of her company.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: You are a fool. You, niece, provide yourself:
If you outstay the time, upon mine honour,
And in the greatness of my word, you die. Exeunt Duke Frederick and Lords.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?
Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.
I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I have more cause.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Thou hast not, cousin;
Prithee, be cheerful: know'st thou not, the duke
Hath banished me, his daughter?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: That he hath not.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: No, hath not? Rosalind lacks then the love
Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one:
Shall we be sundered? shall we part, sweet girl?
No: let my father seek another heir.
Therefore devise with me how we may fly,
Whither to go and what to bear with us;
And do not seek to take your change upon you,
To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out;
For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale,
Say what thou canst, I'll go along with thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Why, whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: To seek my uncle in the forest of Arden.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Alas, what danger will it be to us,
Maids as we are, to travel forth so far!
Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: I'll put myself in poor and mean attire
And with a kind of umber smirch my face;
The like do you: so shall we pass along
And never stir assailants.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Were it not better,
Because that I am more than common tall,
That I did suit me all points like a man?
A gallant curtle-axe upon my thigh,
A boar-spear in my hand; and â in my heart
Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will â
We'll have a swashing and a martial outside,
As many other mannish cowards have
That do outface it with their semblances.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page;
And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
But what will you be called?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Something that hath a reference to my state
No longer Celia, but Aliena.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: But, cousin, what if we assayed to steal
The clownish fool out of your father's court?
Would he not be a comfort to our travel?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: He'll go along o'er the wide world with me;
Leave me alone to woo him. Let's away,
And get our jewels and our wealth together,
Devise the fittest time and safest way
To hide us from pursuit that will be made
After my flight. Now go we in content
To liberty and not to banishment. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter DUKE senior, AMIENS, and two or three Lords, like foresters.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,
Hath not old custom made this life more sweet
Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods
More free from peril than the envious court?
Here feel we not the penalty of Adam,
The seasons' difference, as the icy fang
And churlish chiding of the winter's wind,
Which, when it bites and blows upon my body,
Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say
âThis is no flattery: these are counsellors
That feelingly persuade me what I am.â
Sweet are the uses of adversity,
Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,
Wears yet a precious jewel in his head;
And this our life exempt from public haunt
Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks,
Sermons in stones and good in every thing.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.l: I would not change it. Happy is your grace,
That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
Into so quiet and so sweet a style.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,
Being native burghers of this desert city,
Should in their own confines with forked heads
Have their round haunches gored.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Indeed, my lord,
The melancholy Jaques grieves at that,
And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp
Than doth your brother that hath banished you.
to-day my Lord of Amiens and myself
Did steal behind him as he lay along
Under an oak whose antique root peeps out
Upon the brook that brawls along this wood:
To the which place a poor sequestered stag,
That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt,
Did come to languish, and indeed, my lord,
The wretched animal heaved forth such groans
That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
Almost to bursting, and the big round tears
Coursed one another down his innocent nose
In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool,
Much marked of the melancholy Jaques,
Stood on the extremest verge of the swift brook,
Augmenting it with tears.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: But what said Jaques?
Did he not moralize this spectacle?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: O, yes, into a thousand similes.
First, for his weeping into the needless stream;
âPoor deer,â quoth he, âthou makest a testament
As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more
To that which had too much:â then, being there alone,
Left and abandoned of his velvet friends,
â'Tis right:â quoth he; âthus misery doth part
The flux of company:â anon a careless herd,
Full of the pasture, jumps along by him
And never stays to greet him; âAy,â quoth Jaques,
âSweep on, you fat and greasy citizens;
'Tis just the fashion: wherefore do you look
Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?â
Thus most invectively he pierceth through
The body of the country, city, court,
Yea, and of this our life, swearing that we
Are mere usurpers, tyrants and what's worse,
To fright the animals and to kill them up
In their assigned and native dwelling-place.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: And did you leave him in this contemplation?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting
Upon the sobbing deer.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Show me the place:
I love to cope him in these sullen fits,
For then he's full of matter.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: I'll bring you to him straight Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Can it be possible that no man saw them?
It cannot be: some villains of my court
Are of consent and sufferance in this.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: I cannot hear of any that did see her.
The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,
Saw her a-bed, and in the morning early
They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.l: My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft
Your grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
Hisperia, the princess' gentlewoman,
Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
Your daughter and her cousin much commend
The parts and graces of the wrestler
That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;
And she believes, where ever they are gone,
That youth is surely in their company.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither;
If he be absent, bring his brother to me;
I'll make him find him: do this suddenly,
And let not search and inquisition quail
To bring again these foolish runaways. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: What, my young master? O my gentle master!
O my sweet master! O you memory
Of old Sir Rowland! why, what make you here?
Why are you virtuous? why do people love you?
And wherefore are you gentle, strong and valiant?
Why would you be so fond to overcome
The bonny priser of the humorous duke?
Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
Know you not, master, to some kind of men
Their graces serve them but as enemies?
No more do yours: your virtues, gentle master,
Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.
O, what a world is this, when what is comely
Envenoms him that bears it!

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: O unhappy youth!
Come not within these doors; within this roof
The enemy of all your graces lives:
Your brother â no, no brother; yet the son â
Yet not the son, I will not call him son
Of him I was about to call his father â
Hath heard your praises, and this night he means
To burn the lodging where you use to lie
And you within it: if he fail of that,
He will have other means to cut you off.
I overheard him and his practices.
This is no place; this house is but a butchery:
Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: No matter whither, so you come not here.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food?
Or with a base and boisterous sword enforce
A thievish living on the common road?
This I must do, or know not what to do:
Yet this I will not do, do how I can;
I rather will subject me to the malice
Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: But do not so. I have five hundred crowns,
The thrifty hire I saved under your father,
Which I did store to be my foster-nurse
When service should in my old limbs lie lame
And unregarded age in corners thrown:
Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold;
All this I give you. Let me be your servant:
Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty;
For in my youth I never did apply
Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood,
Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
The means of weakness and debility;
Therefore my age is as a lusty winter,
Frosty, but kindly: let me go with you;
I'll do the service of a younger man
In all your business and necessities.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: O good old man, how well in thee appears
The constant service of the antique world,
When service sweat for duty, not for meed!
Thou art not for the fashion of these times,
Where none will sweat but for promotion,
And having that, do choke their service up
Even with the having: it is not so with thee.
But, poor old man, thou prunest a rotten tree,
That cannot so much as a blossom yield
In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry
But come thy ways; we'll go along together,
And ere we have thy youthful wages spent,
We'll light upon some settled low content.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: Master, go on, and I will follow thee,
To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
From seventeen years till now almost fourscore
Here lived I, but now live here no more.
At seventeen years many their fortunes seek;
But at fourscore it is too late a week:
Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
Than to die well and not my master's debtor. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and TOUCHSTONE.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's
apparel and to cry like a woman; but I must
comfort the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose
ought to show itself courageous to petticoat:
therefore courage, good Aliena!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I pray you, bear with me; I cannot go no further.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear
you; yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you, for
I think you have no money in your purse.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Well, this is the forest of Arden.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I
was at home, I was in a better place: but travellers
must be content.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.
Look you, who comes here; a young man and an old in
solemn talk.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: That is the way to make her scorn you still.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her!

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: I partly guess; for I have loved ere now.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess,
Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover
As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow:
But if thy love were ever like to mine â
As sure I think did never man love so â
How many actions most ridiculous
Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: O, thou didst then ne'er love so heartily!
If thou remember'st not the slightest folly
That ever love did make thee run into,
Thou hast not loved:
Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,
Wearing thy hearer in thy mistress' praise,
Thou hast not loved:
Or if thou hast not broke from company
Abruptly, as my passion now makes me,
Thou hast not loved.
O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe! Exit.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Alas, poor shepherd! searching of thy wound,
I have by hard adventure found mine own.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: And I mine. I remember, when I was in love I
broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that
for coming a-night to Jane Smile; and I remember
the kissing of her batler and the cow's dugs that
her pretty chopped hands had milked; and I remember
the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom
I took two cods and, giving her them again, said
with weeping tears âWear these for my sake.â We
that are true lovers run into strange capers;
but as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in
love mortal in folly.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Thou speakest wiser than thou art ware of.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I
break my shins against it.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Jove, Jove! this shepherd's passion
Is much upon my fashion.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: And mine; but it grows something stale with me.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: I pray you, one of you question yond man
If he for gold will give us any food:
I faint almost to death.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.l: Holla, you clown!

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Peace, fool; he's not thy kinsman.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.l: Your betters, sir.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Else are they very wretched.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Peace, I say. Good even to you, friend.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold
Can in this desert place buy entertainment,
Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed:
Here's a young maid with travel much oppressed
And faints for succour.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Fair sir, I pity her
And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,
My fortunes were more able to relieve her;
But I am shepherd to another man
And do not shear the fleeces that I graze:
My master is of churlish disposition
And little recks to find the way to heaven
By doing deeds of hospitality:
Besides, his cote, his flocks and bounds of feed
Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now,
By reason of his absence, there is nothing
That you will feed on; but what is, come see,
And in my voice most welcome shall you be.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile,
That little cares for buying any thing.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty,
Buy thou the cottage, pasture and the flock,
And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: And we will mend thy wages. I like this place,
And willingly could waste my time in it.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Assuredly the thing is to be sold:
Go with me: if you like upon report
The soil, the profit and this kind of life,
I will your very faithful feeder be
And buy it with your gold right suddenly. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.l: Under the greenwood tree
Who loves to lie with me,
And turn his merry note
Unto the sweet bird's throat,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
Here shall he see
No enemy
But winter and rough weather.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: More, more, I prithee, more.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck
melancholy out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs.
More, I prithee, more.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: My voice is ragged: I know I cannot please you.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I do not desire you to please me; I do desire
you to sing. Come, more; another stanzo: call you 'em
stanzos?

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: What you will, Monsieur Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me nothing.
Will you sing?

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: More at your request than to please myself.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I'll thank
you; but that they call compliment is like the
encounter of two dog-apes, and when a man thanks
me heartily, methinks I have given him a penny
and he renders me the beggarly thanks. Come, sing; and
you that will not, hold your tongues.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: Well, I'll end the song. Sirs, cover the while;
the duke will drink under this tree. He hath been all
this day to look you.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is
too disputable for my company: I think of as many
matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no
boast of them. Come, warble, come.

lg.l: Who doth ambition shun
And loves to live i' the sun,
Seeking the food he eats
And pleased with what he gets,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
Here shall he see
No enemy
But winter and rough weather.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I'll give you a verse to this note that I made
yesterday in despite of my invention.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: And I'll sing it.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Thus it goes: â

lg.l: If it do come to pass
That any man turn ass,
Leaving his wealth and ease,
A stubborn will to please,
Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame:
Here shall he see
Gross fools as he,
And if he will come to me.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: What's that âducdameâ?

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a
circle. I'll go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, I'll
rail against all the first-born of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.ab: And I'll go seek the duke: his banquet is prepared.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.ab: Dear master, I can go no further: O, I die for
food! Here lie I down, and measure out my grave.
Farewell, kind master.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Why, how now, Adam! no greater heart in thee?
Live a little; comfort a little; cheer thyself
a little. If this uncouth forest yield any thing
savage, I will either be food for it or bring it
for food to thee. Thy conceit is nearer death
than thy powers. For my sake be comfortable; hold
death awhile at the arm's end: I will here be
with thee presently; and if I bring thee not
something to eat, I will give thee leave to die:
but if thou diest before I come, thou art a mocker
of my labour. Well said! thou lookest cheerly,
and I'll be with thee quickly. Yet thou liest in
the bleak air: come, I will bear thee to some
shelter; and thou shalt not die for lack of a
dinner, if there live any thing in this desert.
Cheerly, good Adam!

div.head: Act 2, Scene 7
div.stage: The forest. A table set out.
Enter DUKE senior, AMIENS, and Lords like outlaws.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: I think he be transformed into a beast;
For I can no where find him like a man.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: My lord, he is but even now gone hence:
Here was he merry, hearing of a song.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: If he, compact of jars, grow musical,
We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
Go, seek him: tell him I would speak with him. Enter JAQUES.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: He saves my labour by his own approach.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this,
That your poor friends must woo your company?
What, you look merrily!

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: A fool, a fool! I met a fool i' the forest,
A motley fool; a miserable world!
As I do live by food, I met a fool;
Who laid him down and basked him in the sun,
And railed on Lady Fortune in good terms,
In good set terms and yet a motley fool.
âGood morrow, fool,â quoth I. âNo, sir,â quoth he,
âCall me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune:â
And then he drew a dial from his poke,
And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye,
Says very wisely, âIt is ten o'clock:
Thus we may see,â quoth he, âhow the world wags:
'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine,
And after one hour more 'twill be eleven;
And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe,
And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot;
And thereby hangs a tale.â When I did hear
The motley fool thus moral on the time,
My lungs began to crow like chanticleer,
That fools should be so deep contemplative,
And I did laugh sans intermission
An hour by his dial. O noble fool!
A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: What fool is this?

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier,
And says, if ladies be but young and fair,
They have the gift to know it: and in his brain,
Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit
After a voyage, he hath strange places crammed
With observation, the which he vents
In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!
I am ambitious for a motley coat.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Thou shalt have one.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: It is my only suit;
Provided that you weed your better judgements
Of all opinion that grows rank in them
That I am wise. I must have liberty
Withal, as large a charter as the wind,
To blow on whom I please; for so fools have;
And they that are most galled with my folly,
They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?
The âwhyâ is plain as way to parish church:
He that a fool doth very wisely hit
Doth very foolishly, although he smart,
Not to seem senseless of the bob: if not,
The wise man's folly is anatomized
Even by the squandering glances of the fool.
Invest me in my motley; give me leave
To speak my mind, and I will through and through
Cleanse the foul body of the infected world,
If they will patiently receive my medicine.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: What, for a counter, would I do but good?

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Most mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin:
For thou thyself hast been a libertine,
As sensual as the brutish sting itself;
And all the embossed sores and headed evils,
That thou with license of free foot hast caught,
Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Why, who cries out on pride,
That can therein tax any private party?
Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea,
Till that the weary very means do ebb?
What woman in the city do I name,
When that I say the city-woman bears
The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?
Who can come in and say that I mean her,
When such a one as she such is her neighbour?
Or what is he of basest function
That says his bravery is not on my cost,
Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits
His folly to the mettle of my speech?
There then; how then? what then? Let me see wherein
My tongue hath wronged him: if it do him right,
Then he hath wronged himself; if he be free,
Why then my taxing like a wild goose flies,
Unclaimed of any man. But who comes here? Enter ORLANDO, with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Forbear, and eat no more.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Why, I have eat none yet.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Nor shalt not, till necessity be served.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Of what kind should this cock come of?

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress,
Or else a rude despiser of good manners,
That in civility thou seem'st so empty?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: You touched my vein at first: the thorny point
Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
Of smooth civility: yet am I inland bred
And know some nurture. But forbear, I say:
He dies that touches any of this fruit
Till I and my affairs are answered.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: And you will not be answered with reason,
I must die.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: What would you have? Your gentleness shall force
More than your force move us to gentleness.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I almost die for food; and let me have it.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you:
I thought that all things had been savage here;
And therefore put I on the countenance
Of stern commandment. But what e'er you are
That in this desert inaccessible,
Under the shade of melancholy boughs,
Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time;
If ever you have looked on better days,
If ever been where bells have knolled to church,
If ever sat at any good man's feast,
If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear
And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied,
Let gentleness my strong enforcement be:
In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: True is it that we have seen better days,
And have with holy bell been knolled to church
And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes
Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered:
And therefore sit you down in gentleness
And take upon command what help we have
That to your wanting may be ministered.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Then but forbear your food a little while,
Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn
And give it food. There is an old poor man,
Who after me hath many a weary step
Limped in pure love: till he be first sufficed,
Oppressed with two weak evils, age and hunger,
I will not touch a bit.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Go find him out,
And we will nothing waste till you return.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort! Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:
This wide and universal theatre
Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
Wherein we play in.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: All the world's a stage,
And all the men and women merely players:
They have their exits and their entrances;
And one man in his time plays many parts,
His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,
Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.
Then the whining schoolboy, with his satchel
And shining morning face, creeping like snail
Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,
Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad
Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier,
Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard,
Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel,
Seeking the bubble reputation
Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice,
In fair round belly with good capon lined,
With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,
Full of wise saws and modern instances;
And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
Into the lean and slippered pantaloon,
With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,
His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide
For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice,
Turning again toward childish treble, pipes
And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,
That ends this strange eventful history,
Is second childishness and mere oblivion,
Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans every thing. Re-enter ORLANDO, with ayl-adam.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Welcome. Set down your venerable burden
And let him feed.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I thank you most for him.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: So had you need:
I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Welcome; fall to: I will not trouble you
As yet, to question you about your fortunes.
Give us some music; and, good cousin, sing. SONG.

sp.speaker: Amiens
sp.l: Blow, blow, thou winter wind.
Thou art not so unkind
As man's ingratitude;
Thy tooth is not so keen,
Because thou art not seen,
Although thy breath be rude.
Heigh-ho! sing, heigh-ho! unto the green holly:
Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly:
Then, heigh-ho, the holly!
This life is most jolly.
Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,
That dost not bite so nigh
As benefits forgot:
Though thou the waters warp,
Thy sting is not so sharp
As friend remembered not.
Heigh-ho! sing, etc.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son,
As you have whispered faithfully you were,
And as mine eye doth his effigies witness
Most truly limned and living in your face,
Be truly welcome hither: I am the duke
That loved your father: the residue of your fortune,
Go to my cave and tell me. Good old man,
Thou art right welcome as thy master is.
Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,
And let me all your fortunes understand. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, and OLIVER.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: Not see him since? Sir, sir, that cannot be:
But were I not the better part made mercy,
I should not seek an absent argument
Of my revenge, thou present. But look to it:
Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is;
Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living
Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more
To seek a living in our territory.
Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
Worth seizure do we seize into our hands,
Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth
Of what we think against thee.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: O that your highness knew my heart in this!
I never loved my brother in my life.

sp.speaker: Duke Frederick
sp.l: More villain thou. Well, push him out of doors;
And let my officers of such a nature
Make an extent upon his house and lands:
Do this expediently and turn him going. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love:
And thou, thrice-crowned queen of night, survey
With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,
Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway.
O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books
And in their barks my thoughts I'll character;
That every eye which in this forest looks
Shall see thy virtue witnessed every where.
Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree
The fair, the chaste and unexpressive she. Exit. Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: And how like you this shepherd's life, Master
Touchstone?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a
good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd's
life, it is naught. In respect that it is solitary,
I like it very well; but in respect that it is
private, it is a very vile life. Now, in respect
it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in
respect it is not in the court, it is tedious.
As it is a spare life, look you, it fits my humour
well; but as there is no more plenty in it, it
goes much against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in
thee, shepherd?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: No more but that I know the more one sickens the
worse at ease he is; and that he that wants money,
means and content is without three good friends;
that the property of rain is to wet and fire to
burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep, and that
a great cause of the night is lack of the sun;
that he that hath learned no wit by nature nor
art may complain of good breeding or comes of a very
dull kindred.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in
court, shepherd?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: No, truly.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Then thou art damned.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Nay, I hope.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Truly, thou art damned, like an ill-roasted egg, all
on one side.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: For not being at court? Your reason.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never
sawest good manners; if thou never sawest good
manners, then thy manners must be wicked; and
wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art in a
parlous state, shepherd.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Not a whit, Touchstone: those that are good
manners at the court are as ridiculous in the
country as the behaviour of the country is most
mockable at the court. You told me you salute
not at the court, but you kiss your hands: that
courtesy would be uncleanly, if courtiers were
shepherds.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Instance, briefly; come, instance.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their fells
you know, are greasy.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? and is
not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the
sweat of a man? Shallow, shallow. A better instance, I
say; come.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Besides, our hands are hard.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again. A
more sounder instance, come.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: And they are often tarred over with the surgery
of our sheep: and would you have us kiss tar? The
courtier's hands are perfumed with civet.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Most shallow man! thou wormsmeat, in respect of
a good piece of flesh indeed! Learn of the wise,
and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar,
the very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance,
shepherd.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: You have too courtly a wit for me: I'll rest.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee, shallow man! God
make incision in thee! thou art raw.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat,
get that I wear, owe no man hate, envy no man's
happiness, glad of other men's good, content with
my harm, and the greatest of my pride is to see my
ewes graze and my lambs suck.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the
ewes and the rams together and to offer to get
your living by the copulation of cattle; to be
bawd to a bell-wether, and to betray a she-lamb
of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated, old, cuckoldly
ram, out of all reasonable match. If thou beest
not damned for this, the devil himself will have
no shepherds; I cannot see else how thou shouldst
scape.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress's
brother.
sp.stage: Enter ROSALIND, with a paper, reading.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: From the east to western Ind,
No jewel is like Rosalind.
Her worth, being mounted on the wind,
Through all the world bears Rosalind.
All the pictures fairest lined
Are but black to Rosalind.
Let no face be kept in mind
But the fair of Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I'll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners
and suppers and sleeping-hours excepted: it is the
right butter-women's rank to market.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Out, fool!

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: For a taste:
sp.l: If a hart do lack a hind,
Let him seek out Rosalind.
If the cat will after kind,
So be sure will Rosalind.
Wintered garments must be lined,
So must slender Rosalind.
They that reap must sheaf and bind;
Then to cart with Rosalind.
Sweetest nut hath sourest rind,
Such a nut is Rosalind.
He that sweetest rose will find
Must find love's prick and Rosalind.
sp.ab: This is the very false gallop of verses: why do you
infect yourself with them?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Peace, you dull fool! I found them on a tree.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I'll graft it with you, and then I shall graff
it with a medlar: then it will be the earliest
fruit i' the country; for you'll be rotten ere
you be half ripe, and that's the right virtue of the
medlar.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the
forest judge.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Peace!
Here comes my sister, reading: stand aside.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Why should this a desert be?
For it is unpeopled? No:
Tongues I'll hang on every tree,
That shall civil sayings show:
Some, how brief the life of man
Runs his erring pilgrimage,
That the stretching of a span
Buckles in his sum of age;
Some, of violated vows
'Twixt the souls of friend and friend:
But upon the fairest boughs,
Or at every sentence end,
Will I Rosalinda write,
Teaching all that read to know
The quintessence of every sprite
Heaven would in little show.
Therefore Heaven Nature charged
That one body should be filled
With all graces wide-enlarged:
Nature presently distilled
Helen's cheek, but not her heart,
Cleopatra's majesty,
Atalanta's better part,
Sad Lucretia's modesty.
Thus Rosalind of many parts
By heavenly synod was devised,
Of many faces, eyes and hearts,
To have the touches dearest prized.
Heaven would that she these gifts should have,
And I to live and die her slave.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O most gentle Jupiter! what tedious homily of
love have you wearied your parishioners withal, and
never cried âHave patience, good peopleâ!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: How now! back, friends! Shepherd, go off a little. Go
with him, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Come, shepherd, let us make an honourable retreat;
though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and
scrippage.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Didst thou hear these verses?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some
of them had in them more feet than the verses would
bear.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: That's no matter: the feet might bear the verses.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear
themselves without the verse and therefore stood
lamely in the verse.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name
should be hanged and carved upon these trees?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder
before you came; for look here what I found on
a palm tree. I was never so berhymed since
Pythagoras' time, that I was an Irish rat, which I can
hardly remember.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Trow you who hath done this?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Is it a man?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.
Change you colour?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I prithee, who?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: O Lord, Lord! it is a hard matter for friends to
meet; but mountains may be removed with earthquakes
and so encounter.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, but who is it?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, I prithee now with most petitionary vehemence,
tell me who it is.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful
wonderful! and yet again wonderful, and after that,
out of all whooping!

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Good my complexion! dost thou think, though I am
caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose
in my disposition? One inch of delay more is a
South-sea of discovery; I prithee, tell me who
is it quickly, and speak apace. I would thou
couldst stammer, that thou mightst pour this
concealed man out of thy mouth, as wine comes
out of a narrow-mouthed bottle, either too much
at once, or none at all. I prithee, take the cork out
of thy mouth that I may drink thy tidings.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: So you may put a man in your belly.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Is he of God's making? What manner of man? Is his head
worth a hat, or his chin worth a beard?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why, God will send more, if the man will be
thankful: let me stay the growth of his beard, if thou
delay me not the knowledge of his chin.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler's
heels and your heart both in an instant.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, but the devil take mocking: speak, sad brow and
true maid.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I' faith, coz, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Orlando?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Orlando.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Alas the day! what shall I do with my doublet
and hose? What did he when thou sawest him? What
said he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What
makes he here? Did he ask for me? Where remains
he? How parted he with thee? and when shalt thou see
him again? Answer me in one word.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first: 'tis
a word too great for any mouth of this age's
size. To say ay and no to these particulars is more
than to answer in a catechism.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in
man's apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the day
he wrestled?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the
propositions of a lover: but take a taste of my
finding him, and relish it with good observance. I
found him under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: It may well be called Jove's tree, when it drops such
fruit.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Give me audience, good madam.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: There lay he, stretched along, like a wounded knight.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes
the ground.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Cry âhollaâ to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets
unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O, ominous! he comes to kill my heart.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I would sing my song without a burden: thou bring'st
me out of tune.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Do you not know I am a woman? when I think, I must
speak. Sweet, say on.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: You bring me out. Soft! comes he not here?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: 'Tis he: slink by, and note him.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had
as lief have been myself alone.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you
too for your society.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: God buy you: let's meet as little as we can.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I do desire we may be better strangers.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I pray you, mar no more trees with writing love-songs
in their barks.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I pray you, mar no moe of my verses with reading them
ill-favouredly.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Rosalind is your love's name?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Yes, just.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I do not like her name.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was
christened.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: What stature is she of?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Just as high as my heart.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been
acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conned them out
of rings?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from
whence you have studied your questions.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: You have a nimble wit: I think 'twas made of
Atalanta's heels. Will you sit down with me? and
we two will rail against our mistress the world and
all our misery.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I will chide no breather in the world but myself,
against whom I know most faults.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue. I
am weary of you.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found
you.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: He is drowned in the brook: look but in, and you shall
see him.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: There I shall see mine own figure.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I'll tarry no longer with you: farewell, good Signior
Love.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I am glad of your departure: adieu, good Monsieur
Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I will speak to him, like a saucy lackey and
under that habit play the knave with him. Do you hear,
forester?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Very well: what would you?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I pray you, what is't o'clock?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: You should ask me what time o' day: there's no clock
in the forest.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Then there is no true lover in the forest; else
sighing every minute and groaning every hour
would detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that been
as proper?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: By no means, sir: Time travels in divers paces
with divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles
withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops withal
and who he stands still withal.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between
the contract of her marriage and the day it is
solemnized: if the interim be but a se'nnight,
Time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of
seven year.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Who ambles Time withal?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man
that hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily
because he cannot study, and the other lives
merrily because he feels no pain, the one lacking
the burden of lean and wasteful learning, the
other knowing no burden of heavy tedious penury; these
Time ambles withal.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Who doth he gallop withal?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as
softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon
there.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Who stays it still withal?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep
between term and term and then they perceive not how
Time moves.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Where dwell you, pretty youth?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the skirts
of the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Are you native of this place?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase
in so removed a dwelling.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I have been told so of many: but indeed an old
religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who
was in his youth an inland man; one that knew
courtship too well, for there he fell in love.
I have heard him read many lectures against it,
and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched
with so many giddy offences as he hath generally taxed
their whole sex withal.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he
laid to the charge of women?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: There were none principal; they were all like
one another as half-pence are, every one fault
seeming monstrous till his fellow-fault came to match
it.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I prithee, recount some of them.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those
that are sick. There is a man haunts the forest,
that abuses our young plants with carving âRosalindâ
on their barks; hangs odes upon hawthorns and
elegies on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the
name of Rosalind: if I could meet that fancy-monger,
I would give him some good counsel, for he seems to
have the quotidian of love upon him.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I am he that is so love-shaked: I pray you tell me
your remedy.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: There is none of my uncle's marks upon you: he
taught me how to know a man in love; in which cage of
rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: What were his marks?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: A lean cheek, which you have not, a blue eye and
sunken, which you have not, an unquestionable
spirit, which you have not, a beard neglected,
which you have not; but I pardon you for that,
for simply your having in beard is a younger
brother's revenue: then your hose should be
ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve
unbuttoned, your shoe untied and every thing
about you demonstrating a careless desolation;
but you are no such man; you are rather point-device
in your accoutrements as loving yourself than seeming
the lover of any other.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Me believe it! you may as soon make her that you
love believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter
to do than to confess she does: that is one of
the points in the which women still give the lie
to their consciences. But, in good sooth, are
you he that hangs the verses on the trees, wherein
Rosalind is so admired?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind,
I am that he, that unfortunate he.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Love is merely a madness, and, I tell you, deserves
as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do:
and the reason why they are not so punished and
cured is, that the lunacy is so ordinary that
the whippers are in love too. Yet I profess curing it
by counsel.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Did you ever cure any so?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine
me his love, his mistress; and I set him every
day to woo me: at which time would I, being but
a moonish youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable,
longing and liking, proud, fantastical, apish,
shallow, inconstant, full of tears, full of
smiles, for every passion something and for no
passion truly any thing, as boys and women are
for the most part cattle of this colour; would
now like him, now loathe him; then entertain him,
then forswear him; now weep for him, then spit
at him; that I drave my suitor from his mad humour
of love to a living humour of madness; which was,
to forswear the full stream of the world, and to
live in a nook merely monastic. And thus I cured
him; and this way will I take upon me to wash
your liver as clean as a sound sheep's heart, that
there shall not be one spot of love in't.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I would not be cured, youth.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind
and come every day to my cote and woo me.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Now, by the faith of my love, I will: tell me where it
is.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Go with me to it and I'll show it you: and by
the way you shall tell me where in the forest you
live. Will you go?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: With all my heart, good youth.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you
go?

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY; JAQUES behind.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Come apace, good Audrey: I will fetch up your
goats, Audrey. And how, Audrey? am I the man yet? doth
my simple feature content you?

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Your features! Lord warrant us! what features?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most
capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove in a
thatched house!

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: When a man's verses cannot be understood, nor a
man's good wit seconded with the forward child
Understanding, it strikes a man more dead than
a great reckoning in a little room. Truly, I would the
gods had made thee poetical.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: I do not know what âpoeticalâ is: is it honest in deed
and word? is it a true thing?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most
feigning; and lovers are given to poetry, and
what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they
do feign.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I do, truly; for thou swear'st to me thou art
honest: now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some
hope thou didst feign.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Would you not have me honest?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favoured; for
honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to
sugar.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: A material fool!

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Well, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods
make me honest.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were
to put good meat into an unclean dish.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness!
sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it
may be, I will marry thee, and to that end I have
been with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar of the
next village, who hath promised to meet me in this
place of the forest and to couple us.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I would fain see this meeting.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Well, the gods give us joy!
