sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart,
stagger in this attempt; for here we have no
temple but the wood, no assembly but horn-beasts.
But what though? Courage! As horns are odious,
they are necessary. It is said, âmany a man knows
no end of his goods:â right; many a man has good
horns, and knows no end of them. Well, that is
the dowry of his wife; 'tis none of his own
getting. Horns? Even so. Poor men alone? No, no;
the noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal.
Is the single man therefore blessed? No: as a
walled town is more worthier than a village, so
is the forehead of a married man more honourable
than the bare brow of a bachelor; and by how much
defence is better than no skill, by so much is
a horn more precious than to want. Here comes
Sir Oliver.
Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met: will you
dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go with
you to your chapel?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.ab: Is there none here to give the woman?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I will not take her on gift of any man.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.ab: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not
lawful.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Proceed, proceed: I'll give her.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Good even, good Master What-ye-call't: how do
you, sir? You are very well met: God 'ild you
for your last company: I am very glad to see you: even
a toy in hand here, sir: nay, pray be covered.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Will you be married, motley?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb
and the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and
as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be
married under a bush like a beggar? Get you to
church, and have a good priest that can tell you
what marriage is: this fellow will but join you
together as they join wainscot; then one of you
will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber,
warp, warp.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I am not in the mind but I were better to be
married of him than of another: for he is not
like to marry me well; and not being well married,
it will be a good excuse for me hereafter to leave my
wife.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.

sp.speaker: Touchstone

lg.l: Come, sweet Audrey:
We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.

sp.l: Farewell, good Master Oliver: not, â

lg.l: O sweet Oliver,
O brave Oliver,
Leave me not behind thee:

sp.l: but, â

lg.l: Wind away,
Be gone, I say,
I will not to wedding with thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.ab: 'Tis no matter: ne'er a fantastical knave of them all
shall flout me out of my calling.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Never talk to me; I will weep.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Do, I prithee; but yet have the grace to consider that
tears do not become a man.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: But have I not cause to weep?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: As good cause as one would desire; therefore weep.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: His very hair is of the dissembling colour.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Something browner than Judas's: marry, his kisses are
Judas's own children.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I' faith, his hair is of a good colour.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only
colour.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of
holy bread.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana: a
nun of winter's sisterhood kisses not more
religiously; the very ice of chastity is in them.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and
comes not?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Yes; I think he is not a pickpurse nor a
horse-stealer, but for his verity in love, I do
think him as concave as a covered goblet or a
worm-eaten nut.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Not true in love?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Yes, when he is in; but I think he is not in.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: You have heard him swear downright he was.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: âWasâ is not âis:â besides, the oath of a lover
is no stronger than the word of a tapster; they
are both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends
here in the forest on the duke your father.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I met the duke yesterday and had much question
with him: he asked me of what parentage I was;
I told him, of as good as he; so he laughed and
let me go. But what talk we of fathers, when there is
such a man as Orlando?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: O, that's a brave man! he writes brave verses,
speaks brave words, swears brave oaths and breaks
them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart
of his lover; as a puisny tilter, that spurs his
horse but on one side, breaks his staff like a
noble goose: but all's brave that youth mounts and
folly guides. Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired
After the shepherd that complained of love,
Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,
Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess
That was his mistress.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Well, and what of him?

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.l: If you will see a pageant truly played,
Between the pale complexion of true love
And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,
Go hence a little and I shall conduct you,
If you will mark it.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: O, come, let us remove:
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
Bring us to this sight, and you shall say
I'll prove a busy actor in their play. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me; do not, Phebe;
Say that you love me not, but say not so
In bitterness. The common executioner,
Whose heart the accustomed sight of death makes hard,
Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck
But first begs pardon: will you sterner be
Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops? Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, behind.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: I would not be thy executioner:
I fly thee, for I would not injure thee.
Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye:
'Tis pretty, sure, and very probable,
That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things,
Who shut their coward gates on atomies,
Should be called tyrants, butchers, murderers!
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;
And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee:
Now counterfeit to swoon; why now fall down;
Or if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame,
Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers!
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee:
Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains
Some scar of it; lean upon a rush,
The cicatrice and capable impressure
Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes,
Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not,
Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes
That can do hurt.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: O dear Phebe,
If ever, â as that ever may be near, â
You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,
Then shall you know the wounds invisible
That love's keen arrows make.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: But till that time
Come not thou near me: and when that time comes,
Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not;
As till that time I shall not pity thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: And why, I pray you? Who might be your mother,
That you insult, exult, and all at once,
Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty, â
As, by my faith, I see no more in you
Than without candle may go dark to bed â
Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?
Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?
I see no more in you than in the ordinary
Of nature's sale-work. 'Od's my little life,
I think she means to tangle my eyes too!
No, faith, proud mistress, hope not after it:
'Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,
Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream,
That can entame my spirits to your worship.
You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,
Like foggy south puffing with wind and rain?
You are a thousand times a properer man
Than she a woman: 'tis such fools as you
That makes the world full of ill-favoured children:
'Tis not her glass, but you, that flatters her;
And out of you she sees herself more proper
Than any of her lineaments can show her.
But, mistress, know yourself: down on your knees,
And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love:
For I must tell you friendly in your ear,
Sell when you can: you are not for all markets:
Cry the man mercy; love him; take his offer:
Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
So take her to thee, shepherd: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Sweet youth, I pray you, chide a year together:
I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: He's fallen in love with your foulness and she'll
fall in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast
as she answers thee with frowning looks. I'll
sauce her with bitter words. Why look you so upon me?

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.ab: For no ill will I bear you.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I pray you, do not fall in love with me,
For I am falser than vows made in wine:
Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,
'Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by.
Will you go, sister? Shepherd, ply her hard.
Come, sister. Shepherdess, look on him better,
And be not proud: though all the world could see,
None could be so abused in sight as he.
Come, to our flock. Exeunt Rosalind, Celia and Corin.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might,
âWho ever loved that loved not at first sight?â

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Sweet Phebe, â

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Ha, what say'st thou, Silvius?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Sweet Phebe, pity me.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Where ever sorrow is, relief would be:
If you do sorrow at my grief in love,
By giving love your sorrow and my grief
Were both extermined.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Thou hast my love: is not that neighbourly?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: I would have you.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Why, that were covetousness.
Silvius, the time was that I hated thee,
And yet it is not that I bear thee love;
But since that thou canst talk of love so well,
Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,
I will endure, and I'll employ thee too:
But do not look for further recompense
Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: So holy and so perfect is my love,
And I in such a poverty of grace,
That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
To glean the broken ears after the man
That the main harvest reaps: loose now and then
A scattered smile, and that I'll live upon.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Know'st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Not very well, but I have met him oft:
And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
That the old carlot once was master of.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Think not I love him, though I ask for him;
'Tis but a peevish boy; yet he talks well;
But what care I for words? yet words do well
When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
It is a pretty youth: not very pretty:
But, sure, he's proud, and yet his pride becomes him:
He'll make a proper man: the best thing in him
Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue
Did make offence his eye did heal it up.
He is not very tall; yet for his years he's tall:
His leg is but so so; and yet 'tis well:
There was a pretty redness in his lip,
A little riper and more lusty red
Than that mixed in his cheek; 'twas just the difference
Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
There be some women, Silvius, had they marked him
In parcels as I did, would have gone near
To fall in love with him; but, for my part,
I love him not nor hate him not; and yet
have more cause to hate him than to love him:
For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black and my hair black:
And, now I am remembered, scorned at me:
I marvel why I answered not again:
But that's all one; omittance is no quittance.
I'll write to him a very taunting letter,
And thou shalt bear it: wilt thou, Silvius?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Phebe, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: I'll write it straight;
The matter's in my head and in my heart:
I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Go with me, Silvius. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted
with thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I am so; I do love it better than laughing.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable
fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure
worse than drunkards.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why then, 'tis good to be a post.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which
is emulation, nor the musician's, which is
fantastical, nor the courtier's, which is proud,
nor the soldier's, which is ambitious, nor the
lawyer's, which is politic, nor the lady's, which
is nice, nor the lover's, which is all these:
but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded
of many simples, extracted from many objects,
and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels,
in which my often rumination wraps me in a most
humorous sadness.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason
to be sad: I fear you have sold your own lands
to see other men's; then, to have seen much and
to have nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Yes, I have gained my experience.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: And your experience makes you sad! I had rather
have a fool to make me merry than experience to make
me sad; and to travel for it too!

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind!

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Nay, then, God buy you, and you talk in blank verse.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Farewell, Monsieur Traveller: look you lisp and
wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of
your own country, be out of love with your nativity
and almost chide God for making you that countenance
you are, or I will scarce think you have swam in
a gondola. Why, how now, Orlando! where have you
been all this while? You a lover! And you serve
me such another trick, never come in my sight more.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Break an hour's promise in love! He that will
divide a minute into a thousand parts and break
but a part of the thousandth part of a minute in
the affairs of love, it may be said of him that
Cupid hath clapped him o' the shoulder, but I'll
warrant him heart-whole.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, and you be so tardy, come no more in my sight: I
had as lief be wooed of a snail.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Of a snail?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he
carries his house on his head; a better jointure,
I think, than you make a woman: besides, he brings his
destiny with him.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: What's that?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be
beholding to your wives for: but he comes armed
in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: And I am your Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a Rosalind
of a better leer than you.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday
humour and like enough to consent. What would
you say to me now, an I were your very very Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I would kiss before I spoke.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you
were gravelled for lack of matter, you might take
occasion to kiss. Very good orators, when they
are out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking â God
warn us! â matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: How if the kiss be denied?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new
matter.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress, or I
should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: What, of my suit?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit. Am
not I your Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I take some joy to say you are, because I would be
talking of her.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Well, in her person I say I will not have you.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Then in mine own person I die.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is
almost six thousand years old, and in all this
time there was not any man died in his own person,
videlicet, in a love-cause. Troilus had his brains
dashed out with a Grecian club; yet he did what
he could to die before, and he is one of the
patterns of love. Leander, he would have lived
many a fair year, though Hero had turned nun, if
it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for,
good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the
Hellespont and being taken with the cramp was
drowned: and the foolish chroniclers of that age
found it was âHero of Sestos.â But these are all
lies: men have died from time to time and worms have
eaten them, but not for love.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind, for,
I protest, her frown might kill me.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come,
now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on
disposition, and ask me what you will. I will grant
it.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Then love me, Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: And wilt thou have me?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, and twenty such.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Are you not good?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?
Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry
us. Give me your hand, Orlando. What do you say,
sister?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Pray thee, marry us.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I cannot say the words.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: You must begin, âWill you, Orlando â â

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I will.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, but when?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Why now; as fast as she can marry us.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Then you must say âI take thee, Rosalind, for wife.â

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I might ask you for your commission; but I do
take thee, Orlando, for my husband: there's a
girl goes before the priest; and certainly a woman's
thought runs before her actions.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: So do all thoughts; they are winged.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have
possessed her.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: For ever and a day.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Say âa day,â without the âever.â No, no, Orlando;
men are April when they woo, December when they
wed: maids are May when they are maids, but the
sky changes when they are wives. I will be more
jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over
his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against
rain, more new-fangled than an ape, more giddy
in my desires than a monkey: I will weep for
nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will
do that when you are disposed to be merry; I will
laugh like a hyen, and that when thou art inclined to
sleep.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: But will my Rosalind do so?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: By my life, she will do as I do.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: O, but she is wise.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Or else she could not have the wit to do this:
the wiser, the waywarder: make the doors upon a
woman's wit and it will out at the casement; shut
that and 'twill out at the key-hole; stop that, 'twill
fly with the smoke out at the chimney.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say
âWit, whither wilt?â

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Nay, you might keep that check for it till you met
your wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You
shall never take her without her answer, unless
you take her without her tongue. O, that woman
that cannot make her fault her husband's occasion,
let her never nurse her child herself, for she will
breed it like a fool!

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Alas! dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I must attend the duke at dinner: by two o'clock I
will be with thee again.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Ay, go your ways, go your ways; I knew what you
would prove: my friends told me as much, and I
thought no less: that flattering tongue of yours
won me: 'tis but one cast away, and so, come, death!
Two o'clock is your hour?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Ay, sweet Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend
me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous,
if you break one jot of your promise or come one
minute behind your hour, I will think you the
most pathetical break-promise and the most hollow
lover and the most unworthy of her you call
Rosalind that may be chosen out of the gross band
of the unfaithful: therefore beware my censure and
keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my
Rosalind: so adieu.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such
offenders, and let Time try: adieu.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate:
we must have your doublet and hose plucked over
your head, and show the world what the bird hath done
to her own nest.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou
didst know how many fathom deep I am in love!
But it cannot be sounded: my affection hath an unknown
bottom, like the bay of Portugal.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Or rather, bottomless, that as fast as you pour
affection in, it runs out.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was
begot of thought, conceived of spleen and born
of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses
every one's eyes because his own are out, let
him be judge how deep I am in love. I'll tell
thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando:
I'll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: And I'll sleep.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Which is he that killed the deer?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.ab: Sir, it was I.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Let's present him to the duke, like a Roman
conqueror; and it would do well to set the deer's
horns upon his head, for a branch of victory. Have you
no song, forester, for this purpose?

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.ab: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Sing it: 'tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make
noise enough.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: What shall he have that killed the deer?
His leather skin and horns to wear.
Then sing him home; The rest shall bear this burden.
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn;
It was a crest ere thou wast born:
Thy father's father wore it,
And thy father bore it:
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: How say you now? Is it not past two o'clock? and here
much Orlando!

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain,
he hath ta'en his bow and arrows and is gone forth to
sleep. Look, who comes here.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: My errand is to you, fair youth;
My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this:
I know not the contents; but, as I guess
By the stern brow and waspish action
Which she did use as she was writing of it,
It bears an angry tenor: pardon me:
I am but as a guiltless messenger.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Patience herself would startle at this letter
And play the swaggerer; bear this, bear all:
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;
She calls me proud, and that she could not love me,
Were man as rare as phoenix. 'Od's my will!
Her love is not the hare that I do hunt:
Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,
This is a letter of your own device.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: No, I protest, I know not the contents:
Phebe did write it.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Come, come, you are a fool
And turned into the extremity of love.
I saw her hand: she has a leathern hand,
A freestone-coloured hand; I verily did think
That her old gloves were on, but 'twas her hands:
She has a huswife's hand; but that's no matter:
I say she never did invent this letter;
This is a man's invention and his hand.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Sure, it is hers.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Why, 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style,
A style for challengers; why, she defies me,
Like Turk to Christian: women's gentle brain
Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention,
Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect
Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: So please you, for I never heard it yet;
Yet heard too much of Phebe's cruelty.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.
sp.l: Art thou god to shepherd turned,
That a maiden's heart hath burned?
sp.ab: Can a woman rail thus?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.ab: Call you this railing?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Why, thy godhead laid apart,
Warr'st thou with a woman's heart?
sp.ab: Did you ever hear such railing?
sp.l: Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
That could do no vengeance to me.
sp.ab: Meaning me a beast.
sp.l: If the scorn of your bright eyne
Have power to raise such love in mine,
Alack, in me what strange effect
Would they work in mild aspect!
Whiles you chid me, I did love;
How then might your prayers move!
He that brings this love to thee
Little knows this love in me:
And by him seal up thy mind;
Whether that thy youth and kind
Will the faithful offer take
Of me and all that I can make;
Or else by him my love deny,
And then I'll study how to die.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.ab: Call you this chiding?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Alas, poor shepherd!

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Do you pity him? no, he deserves no pity. Wilt
thou love such a woman? What, to make thee an
instrument and play false strains upon thee! not
to be endured! Well, go your way to her, for I
see love hath made thee a tame snake, and say
this to her: that if she love me, I charge her
to love thee; if she will not, I will never have
her unless thou entreat for her. If you be a true
lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more
company.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Good morrow, fair ones: pray you, if you know,
Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
A sheepcote fenced about with olive-trees?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom:
The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
Left on your right hand brings you to the place.
But at this hour the house doth keep itself;
There's none within.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then should I know you by description;
Such garments and such years: âThe boy is fair,
Of female favour, and bestows himself
Like a ripe sister: the woman low
And browner than her brother.â Are not you
The owner of the house I did inquire for?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Orlando doth commend him to you both,
And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I am: what must we understand by this?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Some of my shame; if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where
This handkercher was stained.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: I pray you, tell it.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: When last the young Orlando parted from you
He left a promise to return again
Within an hour, and pacing through the forest,
Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
Lo, what befell! he threw his eye aside,
And mark what object did present itself:
Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age
And high top bald with dry antiquity,
A wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair,
Lay sleeping on his back: about his neck
A green and gilded snake had wreathed itself,
Who with her head nimble in threats approached
The opening of his mouth; but suddenly,
Seeing Orlando, it unlinked itself,
And with indented glides did slip away
Into a bush: under which bush's shade
A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch,
When that the sleeping man should stir; for 'tis
The royal disposition of that beast
To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead:
This seen, Orlando did approach the man
And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;
And he did render him the most unnatural
That lived amongst men.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: And well he might so do,
For well I know he was unnatural.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: But, to Orlando: did he leave him there,
Food to the sucked and hungry lioness?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so;
But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
And nature, stronger than his just occasion,
Made him give battle to the lioness,
Who quickly fell before him: in which hurtling
From miserable slumber I awaked.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Are you his brother?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Was't you he rescued?

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Was't you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: 'Twas I; but 'tis not I: I do not shame
To tell you what I was, since my conversion
So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: But, for the bloody napkin?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: By and by.
When from the first to last betwixt us two
Tears our recountments had most kindly bathed,
As how I came into that desert place: â
In brief, he led me to the gentle duke,
Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
Committing me unto my brother's love;
Who led me instantly unto his cave,
There stripped himself, and here upon his arm
The lioness had torn some flesh away,
Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted
And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind.
Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound;
And, after some small space, being strong at heart,
He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
To tell this story, that you might excuse
His broken promise, and to give this napkin
Dyed in his blood unto the shepherd youth
That he in sport doth call his Rosalind. Rosalind swoons.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Why, how now, Ganymede! sweet Ganymede!

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: Look, he recovers.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I would I were at home.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: We'll lead you thither.
I pray you, will you take him by the arm?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Be of good cheer, youth: you a man! you lack a man's
heart.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would
think this was well counterfeited! I pray you,
tell your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: This was not counterfeit: there is too great
testimony in your complexion that it was a passion of
earnest.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Counterfeit, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a
man.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: So I do: but, i' faith, I should have been a woman by
right.

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.ab: Come, you look paler and paler: pray you, draw
homewards. Good sir, go with us.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.l: That will I, for I must bear answer back
How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I shall devise something: but, I pray you, commend my
counterfeiting to him. Will you go?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old
gentleman's saying.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile
Martext. But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the
forest lays claim to you.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in the
world: here comes the man you mean.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown: by my
troth, we that have good wits have much to answer for;
we shall be flouting; we cannot hold.

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Good even, Audrey.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: God ye good even, William.

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: And good even to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Good even, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover
thy head; nay, prithee, be covered. How old are you,
friend?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Five and twenty, sir.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: A ripe age. Is thy name William?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: William, sir.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: A fair name. Wast born i' the forest here?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Ay, sir, I thank God.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: âThank God;â a good answer. Art rich?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Faith, sir, so so.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: âSo soâ is good, very good, very excellent good; and
yet it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Why, thou sayest well. I do now remember a saying,
âThe fool doth think he is wise, but the wise
man knows himself to be a fool.â The heathen
philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a grape,
would open his lips when he put it into his mouth;
meaning thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips
to open. You do love this maid?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: I do, sir.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Give me your hand. Art thou learned?

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Then learn this of me: to have, is to have; for
it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being
poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the
one doth empty the other; for all your writers
do consent that ipse is he: now, you are not ipse, for
I am he.

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: Which he, sir?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore,
you clown, abandon, â which is in the vulgar
leave, â the society, â which in the boorish is
company, â of this female, â which in the common is
woman; which together is, abandon the society of
this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or, to
thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I
kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life
into death, thy liberty into bondage: I will deal
in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel;
I will bandy with thee in faction; I will o'errun
thee with policy; I will kill thee a hundred and fifty
ways: therefore tremble, and depart.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: Do, good William.

sp.speaker: William
sp.ab: God rest you merry, sir.

sp.speaker: Corin
sp.ab: Our master and mistress seeks you; come, away, away!

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Trip, Audrey! trip, Audrey! I attend, I attend.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Is't possible that on so little acquaintance you
should like her? that but seeing you should love
her? and loving woo? and, wooing, she should grant?
and will you persever to enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: Neither call the giddiness of it in question,
the poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my
sudden wooing, nor her sudden consenting; but
say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that
she loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy
each other: it shall be to your good; for my
father's house and all the revenue that was old
Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you, and here live
and die a shepherd.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow:
thither will I invite the duke and all's contented
followers. Go you and prepare Aliena; for look you,
here comes my Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: God save you, brother.

sp.speaker: Oliver
sp.ab: And you, fair sister.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear
thy heart in a scarf!

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: It is my arm.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of
a lion.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon
when he showed me your handkercher?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Ay, and greater wonders than that.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: O, I know where you are: nay, 'tis true: there
was never any thing so sudden but the fight of
two rams and Caesar's thrasonical brag of âI
came, saw, and overcame:â for your brother and
my sister no sooner met but they looked, no sooner
looked but they loved, no sooner loved but they
sighed, no sooner sighed but they asked one
another the reason, no sooner knew the reason
but they sought the remedy; and in these degrees
have they made a pair of stairs to marriage which
they will climb incontinent, or else be incontinent
before marriage: they are in the very wrath of
love and they will together; clubs cannot part them.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: They shall be married to-morrow, and I will bid
the duke to the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a
thing it is to look into happiness through another
man's eyes! By so much the more shall I to-morrow
be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much
I shall think my brother happy in having what he
wishes for.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for
Rosalind?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: I can live no longer by thinking.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.
Know of me then, for now I speak to some purpose,
that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit:
I speak not this that you should bear a good
opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know
you are; neither do I labour for a greater esteem
than may in some little measure draw a belief
from you, to do yourself good and not to grace
me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do
strange things: I have, since I was three year
old, conversed with a magician, most profound in
his art and yet not damnable. If you do love
Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries
it out, when your brother marries Aliena, shall
you marry her: I know into what straits of fortune
she is driven; and it is not impossible to me,
if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her
before your eyes to-morrow human as she is and without
any danger.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Speakest thou in sober meanings?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though
I say I am a magician. Therefore, put you in your
best array: bid your friends; for if you will be
married to-morrow, you shall, and to Rosalind,
if you will.
Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness,
To show the letter that I writ to you.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I care not if I have: it is my study
To seem despiteful and ungentle to you:
You are there followed by a faithful shepherd;
Look upon him, love him; he worships you.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: Good shepherd, tell this youth what 'tis to love.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: It is to be all made of sighs and tears;
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: And I for Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: And I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: And I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: It is to be all made of faith and service;
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: And I for Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: And I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: And I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: It is to be all made of fantasy,
All made of passion and all made of wishes,
All adoration, duty, and observance,
All humbleness, all patience and impatience,
All purity, all trial, all observance;
And so am I for Phebe.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: And so am I for Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: And so am I for Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: And so am I for no woman.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Why do you speak too, âWhy blame you me to love you?â

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: Pray you, no more of this; 'tis like the howling
of Irish wolves against the moon.
I will help you, if I can:
I would love you, if I could. To-morrow meet me
all together.
I will marry you, if ever I marry woman, and I'll
be married to-morrow:
I will satisfy you, if ever I satisfied man, and
you shall be married to-morrow:
I will content you, if what pleases you contents
you, and you shall be married to-morrow.
As you love Rosalind, meet:
as you love Phebe, meet: and as I love no woman,
I'll meet. So fare you well: I have left you commands.

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.ab: I'll not fail, if I live.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.ab: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.ab: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: To-morrow is the joyful day, Audrey; to-morrow will we
be married.

sp.speaker: Audrey
sp.ab: I do desire it with all my heart: and I hope it
is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman
of the world. Here come two of the banished duke's
pages.

sp.speaker: First Page
sp.ab: Well met, honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.

sp.speaker: Second Page
sp.ab: We are for you: sit i' the middle.

sp.speaker: First Page
sp.ab: Shall we clap into't roundly, without hawking or
spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only
prologues to a bad voice?

sp.speaker: Second Page
sp.ab: I' faith, i' faith; and both in a tune, like two
gipsies on a horse.

lg.l: It was a lover and his lass,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
That o'er the green corn-field did pass
In spring time, the only pretty ring time,
When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding:
Sweet lovers love the spring.
Between the acres of the rye,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
These pretty country folks would lie,
In spring time, etc.
This carol they began that hour,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
How that a life was but a flower
In spring time, etc.
And therefore take the present time,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino;
For love is crowned with the prime
In spring time, etc.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great
matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untuneable.

sp.speaker: First Page
sp.ab: You are deceived, sir: we kept time, we lost not our
time.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to
hear such a foolish song. God buy you; and God mend
your voices! Come, Audrey.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter DUKE senior, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promised?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: I sometimes do believe, and sometimes do not;
As those that fear they hope, and know they fear. Enter ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHEBE.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: Patience once more, whiles our compact is urged:
You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,
You will bestow her on Orlando here?

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: And you say, you will have her, when I bring her?

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: You say, you'll marry me, if I be willing?

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: That will I, should I die the hour after.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: But if you do refuse to marry me,
You'll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: So is the bargain.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: You say, that you'll have Phebe, if she will?

sp.speaker: Silvius
sp.l: Though to have her and death were both one thing.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I have promised to make all this matter even.
Keep you your word, O duke, to give your daughter;
You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter:
Keep you your word, Phebe, that you'll marry me,
Or else refusing me, to wed this shepherd:
Keep your word, Silvius, that you'll marry her,
If she refuse me: and from hence I go,
To make these doubts all even. Exeunt Rosalind and Celia.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: I do remember in this shepherd boy
Some lively touches of my daughter's favour.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
Methought he was a brother to your daughter:
But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,
And hath been tutored in the rudiments
Of many desperate studies by his uncle,
Whom he reports to be a great magician,
Obscured in the circle of this forest. Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: There is, sure, another flood toward, and these
couples are coming to the ark. Here comes a pair
of very strange beasts, which in all tongues are
called fools.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Salutation and greeting to you all!

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Good my lord, bid him welcome: this is the
motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in
the forest: he hath been a courtier, he swears.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: If any man doubt that, let him put me to my
purgation. I have trod a measure; I have flattered
a lady; I have been politic with my friend, smooth
with mine enemy; I have undone three tailors; I have
had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: And how was that ta'en up?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the
seventh cause.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: How seventh cause? Good my lord, like this fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.ab: I like him very well.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: God 'ild you, sir; I desire you of the like. I
press in here, sir, amongst the rest of the
country copulatives, to swear and to forswear;
according as marriage binds and blood breaks: a
poor virgin, sir, an ill-favoured thing, sir,
but mine own; a poor humour of mine, sir, to take
that that no man else will: rich honesty dwells
like a miser, sir, in a poor house; as your pearl in
your foul oyster.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.ab: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: According to the fool's bolt, sir, and such dulcet
diseases.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: But, for the seventh cause; how did you find the
quarrel on the seventh cause?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: Upon a lie seven times removed: â bear your body
more seeming, Audrey: â as thus, sir. I did dislike
the cut of a certain courtier's beard: he sent
me word, if I said his beard was not cut well,
he was in the mind it was: this is called the
Retort Courteous. If I sent him word again âit
was not well cut,â he would send me word, he cut
it to please himself: this is called the Quip
Modest. If again âit was not well cut,â he disabled
my judgement: this is called the Reply Churlish.
If again âit was not well cut,â he would answer,
I spake not true: this is called the Reproof
Valiant. If again âit was not well cut,â he would
say, I lied: this is called the Countercheck
Quarrelsome: and so to Lie Circumstantial and the Lie
Direct.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial,
nor he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we
measured swords and parted.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?

sp.speaker: Touchstone
sp.ab: O sir, we quarrel in print, by the book; as you
have books for good manners: I will name you the
degrees. The first, the Retort Courteous; the
second, the Quip Modest; the third, the Reply
Churlish; the fourth, the Reproof Valiant; the
fifth, the Countercheck Quarrelsome; the sixth,
the Lie with Circumstance; the seventh, the Lie
Direct. All these you may avoid but the Lie
Direct; and you may avoid that too, with an If.
I knew when seven justices could not take up a
quarrel, but when the parties were met themselves,
one of them thought but of an If, as, âIf you
said so, then I said so;â and they shook hands
and swore brothers. Your If is the only peacemaker;
much virtue in If.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.ab: Is not this a rare fellow, my lord? he's as good at
any thing and yet a fool.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.ab: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse and under the
presentation of that he shoots his wit.

sp.speaker: A person representing Hymen
sp.l: Then is there mirth in heaven,
When earthly things made even
Atone together.
Good duke, receive thy daughter:
Hymen from heaven brought her,
Yea, brought her hither,
That thou mightst join her hand with his
Whose heart within his bosom is.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: To you I give myself, for I am yours.
To Orlando To you I give myself, for I am yours.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

sp.speaker: Orlando
sp.l: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: If sight and shape be true,
Why then, my love adieu!

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.l: I'll have no father, if you be not he:
I'll have no husband, if you be not he:
Nor ne'er wed woman, if you be not she.

sp.speaker: A person representing Hymen
sp.l: Peace, ho! I bar confusion:
'Tis I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events:
Here's eight that must take hands
To join in Hymen's bands,
If truth holds true contents.
You and you no cross shall part:
You and you are heart in heart:
You to his love must accord,
Or have a woman to your lord:
You and you are sure together,
As the winter to foul weather.
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
Feed yourselves with questioning;
That reason wonder may diminish,
How thus we met, and these things finish. SONG.
Wedding is great Juno's crown:
O blessed bond of board and bed!
'Tis Hymen peoples every town;
High wedlock then be honoured:
Honour, high honour and renown,
To Hymen, god of every town!

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me!
Even daughter, welcome, in no less degree.

sp.speaker: Phebe
sp.l: I will not eat my word, now thou art mine;
Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine. Enter JAQUES DE BOYS.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Let me have audience for a word or two:
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
addressed a mighty power; which were on foot,
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here and put him to the sword:
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came;
Where meeting with an old religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise and from the world,
His crown bequeathing to his banished brother,
And all their lands restored to them again
That were with him exiled. This to be true,
I do engage my life.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Welcome, young man;
Thou offer'st fairly to thy brothers' wedding:
To one his lands withheld, and to the other
A land itself at large, a potent dukedom.
First, in this forest let us do those ends
That here were well begun and well begot:
And after, every of this happy number
That have endured shrewd days and nights with us
Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
According to the measure of their states.
Meantime, forget this new-fall'n dignity
And fall into our rustic revelry.
Play, music! And you, brides and bridegrooms all,
With measure heaped in joy, to the measures fall.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly,
The duke hath put on a religious life
And thrown into neglect the pompous court?

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: He hath.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: To him will I: out of these convertites
There is much matter to be heard and learned.
To duke You to your former honour I bequeath;
Your patience and your virtue well deserves it:
To Orlando You to a love that your true faith doth merit:
To Oil. You to your land and love and great allies:
To Silvius1 You to a long and well-deserved bed:
To Touch. And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victualled. So, to your pleasures:
I am for other than for dancing measures.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Stay, Jaques, stay.

sp.speaker: Jaques
sp.l: To see no pastime I: what you would have
I'll stay to know at your abandoned cave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke Senior
sp.l: Proceed, proceed: we'll begin these rites,
As we do trust they'll end, in true delights. A dance. EPILOGUE.

sp.speaker: Rosalind
sp.ab: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue;
but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord
the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs
no bush, 'tis true that a good play needs no
epilogue; yet to good wine they do use good
bushes, and good plays prove the better by the
help of good epilogues. What a case am I in then,
that am neither a good epilogue nor cannot
insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play!
I am not furnished like a beggar, therefore to
beg will not become me: my way is to conjure you;
and I'll begin with the women. I charge you, O
women, for the love you bear to men, to like as
much of this play as please you: and I charge
you, O men, for the love you bear to women â as I
perceive by your simpering, none of you hates
them â that between you and the women the play may
please. If I were a woman I would kiss as many
of you as had beards that pleased me, complexions
that liked me and breaths that I defied not: and,
I am sure, as many as have good beards or good
faces or sweet breaths will, for my kind offer, when I
make curtsy, bid me farewell.
